headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Today: FAA To Hold Emergency Meeting After 7 Runway Close Calls; One-On-One With Duke Basketball Legend Coach K.; Today: Cohen Returns To Testify Before Manhattan Grand Jury. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: JOHN KIRBY, NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL COORDINATOR FOR STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS
utterances.sentences: We'll monitor it, obviously, to make sure that there's no threat resulting from this training exercise to our national security interests or those of our allies and partners in the region. But nations train and we do it all the time. We'll watch it as best we can.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right, John Kirby joining us from the White House lawn. John, always a pleasure. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KIRBY
utterances.sentences: You bet. Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You as well.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, interesting to hear him say they may never recover that drone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They may never recover and --

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- that they -- he said -- the words were they're doing everything they can. They're taking steps to minimize people from exploiting it, but that's not a 100 percent --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: AKA Russia.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Do you remember all the intelligence they got out of that Iranian drone that they were able to -- that was downed? How when they found all those U.S. components, et cetera. I mean, you can get a lot from these things.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And it's interesting. He said because the Russian ambassador and the Russian spokesperson is comparing this. He's saying it's apple to oranges. Just saying flying over the Pacific or the Atlantic would be the equivalent of flying over the Black Sea. Not the same thing.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Also, Russian claims they're not at war in Ukraine, too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right, exactly. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So there's that.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Great interview.All right. Also this morning we are tracking another close call on an airport runway. It's under investigation for this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLER
utterances.sentences: United 2003, cancel takeoff clearance!UNITED 2003 PILOT:  Aborting takeoff, aborting takeoff, United 2003. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Happening this morning, the FAA is going to hold an emergency safety summit as the agency is now investigating its seventh near-miss of commercial airplanes on the runway. The latest one just happened last week at Reagan National Airport in Arlington, Virginia.CNN's aviation correspondent Pete Muntean joins us now. Pete, I'm flying into Reagan in just a few hours from now. This is now the seventh incident just this year alone. We're only in March.

utterances.speaker: PETE MUNTEAN, CNN AVIATION CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, Kaitlan, this underscores just how serious this problem is. And this safety summit that the FAA is holding today is the first it has had since 2009. That was after a fatal crash. In this latest string of incidents nobody has been killed but the FAA says it's simply not waiting for a catastrophe.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) MUNTEAN (voice-over):  It is a runaway problem on America's runways from Hawaii to the latest incident at Reagan National Airport outside Washington, D.C.

utterances.speaker: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLER
utterances.sentences: United 2003, cancel takeoff clearance!UNITED 2003 PILOT:  Aborting takeoff, aborting takeoff, United 2003. MUNTEAN (voice-over):  Today, the Federal Aviation Administration is holding an emergency safety summit bringing together Transportation Sec. Pete Buttigieg, airlines, investigators, and regulators. It follows seven so-called runway incursions involving commercial airlines since the start of this year -- an issue that landed on Capitol Hill last week. SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TX):  The numerous recent near-misses by airlines just this year are very troubling. MUNTEAN (voice-over):  It was the latest grilling for FAA acting administrator Billy Nolen who insisted to lawmakers and passengers that flying is safe. In announcing the summit, Nolen said the FAA "...will examine which mitigations are working and why others appear to not be as effective as they once were."

utterances.speaker: BILLY NOLEN, ACTING ADMINISTRATOR, FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION
utterances.sentences: The FAA absolutely has a grasp on this situation and it's something that we look at every day.MUNTEAN (voice-over):  Also in the meeting, representatives from airline unions. American Airlines Capt. Dennis Tajer says no meeting is necessary to know airlines are stressed to the max, still struggling to bounce back from the pandemic. CAPTAIN DENNIS TRAJER, ALLIED PILOTS' ASSOCIATION:  The dead (PH) is right behind me. It's happening out there. These incidents -- things that we've been talking about well over a year ago are starting to show up on the flight deck and in operations. MUNTEAN (voice-over):  So far, the FAA sees no apparent common cause of these incidents -- a top concern for the National Transportation Safety Board.

utterances.speaker: JENNIFER HOMENDY, CHAIR, NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION SAFETY BOARD
utterances.sentences: Just because we are the safest in the world doesn't mean that we'll continue. It only takes one -- one serious tragedy to change all of that.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: MUNTEAN
utterances.sentences: The NTSB says it is aware but not yet launching an investigation into this latest incident at Reagan National Airport.Transportation Sec. Pete Buttigieg just sent a letter to all participants of today's meeting saying we must identify the key risk factors and common causes of these incidents right now -- Kaitlan.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think a lot of people want those answers. Pete Muntean, thank you.On "CNN PRIMETIME" this week we're going to get a closer look at all of America's aviation problems. You just heard from Pete there. We're going to hear from passengers, flight crew members, and aviation experts. That's tomorrow night, 9:00 p.m. eastern. Kate Bolduan is going to host "FLIGHT RISK: TURBULENT TIMES FOR AIR TRAVEL."

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Forty-two seasons, five national championships, and more than 1,000 wins. If you don't like Duke basketball don't watch what's next. I sat down with the legendary Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski to talk about his journey and what it's like not to be on the sidelines for the first time.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MIKE KRZYZEWSKI, FORMER BASKETBALL COACH, DUKE UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: You want a quick story.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: OK, Jason --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There are legends in basketball so famous you know them by one name -- Jordan, Kobe, LeBron. And then there's a legend whose status is so iconic you know him by one letter -- K, as in Coach K. For 42 seasons, Mike Krzyzewski served as the head coach for the Duke Blue Devils. He won 1,129 games at Duke, including five national championships.So I went down to North Carolina to sit with him to talk about leadership ahead of his first March Madness since retirement and got some coaching wisdom. And also, he told me what is more important than winning. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: It's a pretty cool view and --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- all the banners and --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's all your national championships.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: The five, yes. Then Final Fours and ACC Championships.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You're often described by people in profiles of you as the son of a cleaning woman and an elevator operator, but I don't think that's how you would describe your parents.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: No. My parents were the basis of who me and my brother became. They taught us the dignity of work.I even tell my teams, for years, I want you to be as tough as your mother and just think about your mother. Was there ever a day that she didn't show up? Did you ever see her sick? Did you ever see her tired? I never saw my mom sick or tired. I saw her every day doing everything that she could possibly do to make it nice for me and my brother, Bill. I didn't appreciate it until later in life. And my dad died when I was a senior at West Point. He didn't go by the name Krzyzewski. He went by the name Cross because he was always afraid of losing his job because there was a lot of ethnic discrimination at that time. I didn't realize all the things that my parents --

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- gave up.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Hid? Your parents didn't even want you guys to learn to speak Polish.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Polish -- right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: And I didn't find out this until later. They didn't want us to have an accent because they were afraid -- again, during that time somebody with a vowel at the end of their name made them looked at differently and they were concerned.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They were trying to protect you.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: They were trying to protect me and my brother.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So much so it wasn't on his tombstone until --

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. He was in World War II as William Cross. And so when he died and we were a low-income family, the government provides a tombstone. It said Cross. And we weren't able to change that until my mom passed and then my brother and I made sure it said Krzyzewski.You know, I was fortunate to be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame in 2001 and one of the parts of the speech and probably the most emotional for me was I said I wish my mom and dad were here tonight -- I'm going to start crying -- to see a Krzyzewski go into the Hall of Fame. It was emotional then; it's emotional now because I recognize just the life they led to make sure me and Bill would be taken care of -- amazing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How much of what you've done and how you've led and carried on this name so proudly -- it's so famous. I just walked in the Krzyzewski Center.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. They couldn't find another name for it so they put one that no one could pronounce.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I love this picture.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's -- you can tell she's --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Proud.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- proud.I've been married 53 years to Mickie and we knew that it was going to be a partnership. I call it two is better than one if two can act as one, and we were able to act as one. That's my family. Whenever we played in the Olympics we brought everybody.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You did?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You did a lot of it all together.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. I have three daughters.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They hold you down here?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: They have -- whatever humility I did not have they tried to interject in me over and over. So when there used to be family dinners --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- and people would eat together, and I'd be sitting at a table with my four girls and we're playing Carolina or we -- or Maryland or whatever, and we just won a big game. They were talking and nothing is said --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: About your win.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Or about the game. My wife did a great thing, Poppy. When all my girls were growing up we never had anything basketball in the house. The players would come over but there weren't trophies, pictures.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There was no shrine to Coach K in your house.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: There is -- there is no shrine, and there shouldn't be, you know?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, there are in some people's houses.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. Now because it's just me and Mickie and our dog coach --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There is a shrine?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, I'm in a basement office. Well, the lower level --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- and I can put anything I want in there. So whenever I need my ego boosted I go down there and start looking and say man, you were really good. No, I don't do that. HARLOW

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: I do. Usually, not a lot but later at night when all the lights are out and there might be just a little bit on the national championship banners or whatever. You walk in and you feel like you're in a field of dreams.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is your field of dreams.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, you feel like I better get out of here because the basketball gods are going to play pickup here in a little bit.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There are stars -- there are star players, but we've seen in college basketball, in the NBA that when you just put a bunch of stars together it often doesn't work.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: You've heard that expression leave your egos at the door? I hate that expression.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: I hate it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Bring your ego?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Bring everything you've got. Bring who you are. Why wouldn't you bring -- why would you leave something you are --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: To make room for others?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: No, no. We should make the room bigger. You're not confined by the room and when you bring all the egos in and put them under one umbrella that's what we did for you -- and it said USA on it. And then you develop common ground.Quick -- you want a quick story.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: OK, Jason --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I want all the stories.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Jason Kidd -- the first practice, our captain Hall of Famer leading a fast break drill. Dwyane Wade is in one lane, LeBron's in another, and the ball is going everywhere. So I bring them together. Like, I know we can't play like this. And before I say anything J. Kidd says "Coach, I'll tone it down."And immediately, Kobe, LeBron, Dwyane said no, no, no. We've never played with you -- with a talent like you. We'll adapt to you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. It was one of the great moments in my coaching career where I saw talent say come on, talent, give me more. [07

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: It's like the piano player telling the sax player come on, go -- I can play the piano better. You know, the singer. And all of a sudden if you can get everyone playing with all their talent why wouldn't you want talent to maximize?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: And it doesn't mean you have to give up talent to maximize it. And if all that works together, wow.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: How many presidents have you met?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All of them --

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: -- all of them.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- in your lifetime?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: The -- who were -- when we won --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: And 41, President Bush, became a close friend.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's you and Kobe.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is U.S. Thanks for all the golden moments.This is a great book for me because each player gave their quote.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So can we read what LeBron said about you?

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: "He allows us to play the game of basketball and just go out there and have fun. But at the same time, he wants us to be perfect. We should expect perfection and that is what he is about. We like that. We like that kind of challenge."

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Read the last line Kobe said about you.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: "Coach K. is one of the best coaches of all time, period. No question about it." HARLOW

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: We're all better for held accountable and how you hold players accountable along the years change but you still have to hold them accountable.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You've been tough on them -- very.

utterances.speaker: KRZYZEWSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, you hold them accountable. And sometimes there's nobody that holds the leader accountable. It's on you. It's I did it. You know, I need to change. And it was always not about winning and losing for me. It was about being worthy of winning.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was great, Poppy, and you did --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He's great.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And he's great but you did a fantastic job. I can tell --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- that he likes you and pulling it out of you. So can I just -- we talked about this. Leave your egos at the door.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He doesn't like that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It isn't -- and I don't believe that either. I think -- and when people always say you have a big ego -- Poppy has a big ego -- it's like great. Poppy has earned the right to have it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Really? I --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I mean, I'm just saying that --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I never thought that way and he changed --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- my way of thinking.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying in general, people --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- will say that. And people have tried to dim the brightness of the strongest player so that it fits everyone else, and that is the wrong thing to do. You encourage everyone --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Everyone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- to -- the strongest player to lift everyone up. That has always been my motto. And so it's great to have that reinforcement.Leave your egos at the door -- the wrong thing. I thought it was fantastic. And we'll get --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Can I say --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- to the dog thing in a second but it looks like Kaitlan.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, that wasn't even -- that wasn't even where I was going to go. But I was going to say -- I mean, this is no secret about me. I often think that some of the wisest people in our current society --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- are often coaches.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Because they're not just coming up with play calls and depth charts --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- they're coaching and shaping young men and women into what they are.I mean, obviously, I think Nick Saban is a big part of this but hearing him talk about the mentality of that and maximizing talent and making people be their best --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- and bring everything you've got.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You've taught me that on this show about coaches and I've had a friendship with Coach K. for a few years. And I don't know a lot about basketball -- you guys know that -- but I wanted to talk to him because of the way he leads. And he made me think differently about how I operate. That's how significant hearing from him was --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Because it applies to you even, not just a basketball player.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- it applies to me, it applies to all of us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All of us. It is -- that is a leader.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The best.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That is a leader --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The best. LEMON

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- when people are playing out of position and when they're in position.But I didn't think that's where you were going but I -- you and I both perked up when he -- when we heard his dog was named Coach. I'm like that's a great name and you said you want to name your dog Coach.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I literally texted my dad that. I said when I -- when I get a dog eventually -- probably in like 50 years -- I'm going to name it Coach.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Just leave --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'll -- and I'll name mine Put Me In.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'll just leave it at --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And it'll be Put Me In, Coach.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I will just leave it at this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What he has done for the Krzyzewski name, his parents would be very, very proud.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, Donald Trump's former attorney and fixer Michael Cohen expects to go back before a Manhattan grand jury today and finish answering questions about hush money payments to Stormy Daniels. Cohen testified for about three hours Monday he handled the payments to the adult film actress before the 2016 election.The D.A. is investigating Trump's alleged role in those payments. Prosecutors are signaling that a criminal indictment for Trump could be near. CNN's Kara Scannell joins us now with what we are expecting to hear today. So, good morning. What would a -- what are we expecting today?

utterances.speaker: KARA SCANNELL, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, good morning, guys.So, today, Michael Cohen will be back before the grand jury. As you said, he was there on Monday for three hours. And just remember, he was such a central player in these hush money payments so he will be explaining to the grand jury his communications with the former president. You know, remember, he pleaded guilty to a federal case in which he said that Trump had -- he made these payments in coordination with and at the direction of Donald Trump. So he can put the jury in the room and lay out what his version of the case is and what he knows about this. So, certainly, a significant witness. And what seems to be given the parade of witnesses that have been in, one of the last that will be going before the grand jury.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, and we'll be paying -- we'll be watching, Kara. We'll be covering it. Thank you very much. We appreciate it, Kara Scannell.CNN THIS MORNING continues right now.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: This is CNN breaking news.
